title: KKR Leverages Operating Performance on Strong Balance Sheet
text:
KKR Leverages Operating Performance on Strong Balance Sheet By Robert Karr 2 hours ago  
( Continued from Prior Part ) Realizations 
KKR & Co. L.P. (KKR) has invested approximately $1.4 billion from its balance sheet in the first half of 2015. The company has also realized almost $1.4 billion during the same period. Its major realizations include the following: A partial stake sale of Walgreens Boots Alliance generated $212 million. Monetization proceeds from calling and sale of collateralized debt obligations totaled $237 million. Proceeds from the credit portfolio totaled $188 million. Sale of the stake in Bioment resulted in $163 million. 
KKR’s major deployments include the following: KKR invested an additional $200 million in WMI Holdings along with third-party capital. KKR expanded its real estate credit division with a 12-member team. It deployed $210 million in 1H15. KKR made a $130 million investment from Action Partners, an Asia-focused hedge fund. Moderate leverage 
KKR’s debt-to-equity ratio deteriorated in the second quarter. The company’s total debt obligations stood at $2.7 billion as of June 30, 2015, compared to $2.2 billion as of December 31, 2014. Its debt-to-equity ratio increased to 0.25x compared to 0.22x in the last fiscal year. In spite of an increase in leverage, KKR’s balance sheet remains strong and moderately leveraged. The company is using debt financing to fund some of its acquisitions in order to take advantage of lower interest rates. 
KKR’s total debt-to-assets stood at 16.5%, the lowest among its alternative investment peers that form part of the iShares US Financials ETF (IYF). In comparison, KKR’s peers posted the following returns on equity: The Carlyle Group (CG) posted 48%. Blackstone Group (BX) posted 28%. Apollo Global Management (APO) posted 65%.
